summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, requesting and obtaining approval for travel related to the Epstein investigation (case 2018R01618). The emails detail planned trips for victim interviews in Los Angeles, West Palm Beach, and Stockholm, Sweden, between March 2019 and February 2020.

connections.description: Both are part of the same investigation team traveling for interviews related to the Epstein case.

events.title: Initial Travel Request for Florida Interviews
events.description: Assistant U.S. Attorney S requests permission to travel to West Palm Beach/Fort Lauderdale for meetings and interviews related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Travel Approval for Florida Interviews
events.description: Travel request for meetings and interviews in West Palm Beach for the Epstein investigation is approved.

events.title: Travel Request for Florida Victim Interviews
events.description: Request for travel to West Palm Beach for approximately three days to interview victims, with plans to reserve a hotel conference room.

events.title: Travel Request for LA Victim Interview
events.description: Request for travel to Los Angeles for a victim interview, with plans to reserve a hotel conference room.

events.title: Travel Request for LA Interview
events.description: Request for travel to Los Angeles for an interview on November 14.

events.title: Travel Request for LA Interviews
events.description: Request for travel to Los Angeles for an interview or interviews on December 16 and/or 17.

events.title: Travel Approval for Sweden Trip
events.description: Travel request for an interview near Stockholm, Sweden, is approved.

events.title: Planned Travel to Stockholm
events.description: Specific flight booking requested for travel from JFK to Stockholm with a layover in London for an interview.

keyFacts: The document references the ongoing federal investigation 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618', described as 'an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity'.
The investigation team was conducting victim interviews in multiple locations, including Los Angeles, West Palm Beach, and internationally in Stockholm, Sweden, between March 2019 and February 2020.
Travel requests frequently included plans to reserve hotel conference rooms for conducting interviews.
The correspondence shows a pattern of internal approval processes for investigative travel within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.
The international trip to Sweden in February 2020 indicates the investigation had an international dimension requiring overseas interviews.
